Award.AwardTitle: Actively Building the Drive to Achieve through Everyday Engineering Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Having passion and perseverance for long-term goals or the drive to achieve is potentially important to individuals trying to achieve the challenging, long-term goal of attaining an engineering degree, which requires not only talent but also focused and sustained application over a long period. This project is investigating the role of active learning in building passion and perseverance through a longitudinal observational research design.

As a result of their natural progression through the curricula, students have widely varying experiences along the active-learning continuum, from low quantity and quality, to high. This highly diverse engineering-learning ecology presents a unique opportunity to study the association between active learning and the growth of passion and perseverance. This project is developing a smartphone application (app) for participants to measure the quantity and quality of active learning they experience. These data, along with extensive measures of other psychological traits and student achievement, are elements of a model that will clarify the relationship between active learning, passion and perseverance growth, and student achievement. Results from this study potentially will improve the retention and graduation rates of all STEM students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Grit -- defined as passion and perseverance for long-term goals -- is likely to be important to individuals trying to achieve the challenging, long-term goal of attaining an engineering degree, which requires not only talent but also its focused and sustained application over a long period.  This project investigated the role of active learning in building grit.  A longitudinal observational research design was implemented to answer this question.  As a result of their natural progression through the curricula, students have widely varying experiences along the active-learning continuum, from low quantity and quality, to high.  This highly diverse engineering-learning ecology presents a unique opportunity to study the association between active learning and grit growth.  

The ultimate goal of this project is to improve the retention and graduation rates of all STEM students, which in itself is a societal benefit with implications for the nation's well-being.  Furthermore, because women and underrepresented minorities leave STEM majors at disproportionately higher rates, improvements in retention and graduation for these groups will positively impact the makeup of the STEM workforce.  A second impact of this project is that it adds to the nascent understanding of trait grit.  Grit has received wide coverage in both the popular press and the scientific domain because of its promise for helping us understand an important facet of human behavior -- the will to achieve and succeed.  Findings from this project will help in understanding how to build grit in the specific context of using active learning in a STEM-learning environment.  A third impact is that it adds to the broad research base regarding the benefits of active learning.  While most previous research has focused on the knowledge-acquisition benefits of active learning, this project adds to the much smaller research base about its psychological benefits.  

Grit is theorized to develop as a result of (1) a growth mindset, (2) optimism, and (3) deliberate practice.  Growth mindset is the belief that intelligence is malleable, rather than being a fixed quantity.  Its suspected role in enabling grit growth comes from studies that demonstrated a growth mindset encouraged children to see adversities as opportunities to grow, rather than evidence of low abilities.  That optimism is important to building grit comes from a study of novice teachers placed in under-resourced public schools:  The most successful teachers were those who are the most optimistic.

In this project the focus is on active learning -- evidence-based instructional practices that mimic deliberate practice.  Prior studies demonstrated conclusively that deliberate practice mediated between grit and achievement in the context of Spelling Bee contestants, and we believe it will apply in the engineering-learning context as well.  Deliberate practice has well defined characteristics.  First, it involves activities designed to improve specific aspects of performance.  Second, the activities include the provision of continuous feedback to the participant.  Third, it can be repeated often.  Finally, it is very mentally demanding, which could result in the activities being not inherently pleasant.  These characteristics are closely aligned with those of active learning. 

In order to measure each student's exposure to active learning, a smartphone app called Actively Learning was created in this project and study participants used this app to track their quantity and quality of active learning as they progressed through the first two years of mechanical engineering studies.  With this app, we have been able to observe the patterns by which students study, both in and outside of class meetings.  In addition, we see differences in the efficiency by which students study for the same course.  We believe this app will have additional applications beyond measuring active learning and have already adapted it to measure the level and type of contributions team members make toward a group-based project.  We plan to pursue further development of the app in the future.

Over this relatively brief study period, the 57 participants' average level of grit was unchanged in general.  We have not completed our statistical analysis of the data by, for example, parsing out those students who have experienced high levels of active learning versus those who experienced low levels, and comparing their levels of grit growth.  The analysis is delayed because of the complexity and quantity of data collected.  We have submitted one manuscript for review based on the app development and capabilities, and will complete the data analysis and additional manuscripts by the summer of 2020.
